'}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2016-03-04 05:55:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/614e2b2780907657e4c304b01f8a5642cc83aa2a', 'message': 'Add support for dib based agent ramdisk in lib/ironic

This commit adds support for building and configuring
dib based agent ramdisk for Ironic. The environment
variable IRONIC_DIB_RAMDISK_OPTIONS can be used to
mention the preferred distro to build the ramdisk.
The supported types are: coreos, tinyipa and dib.
By default, lib/ironic will continue building coreos
based IPA ramdisk.

The environment variable IRONIC_DIB_RAMDISK_OPTIONS
specifies the options for disk-image-create command
and the platform on which to build the dib based
ironic-python-agent ramdisk.
Default value for IRONIC_DIB_RAMDISK_OPTIONS
is "ubuntu" when 'dib' is the selected distro.

Closes-Bug: 1510797

Change-Id: I0b7f45b87f92b739c0926f2de6c134f9d4e426bb
'}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2016-03-04 16:50:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/f0c87fffcec2de19fe26d7a0a0488a3356f4a8b2', 'message': "Add support for dib based agent ramdisk in lib/ironic

This commit adds support for building and configuring
dib based agent ramdisk for Ironic. The environment
variable IRONIC_RAMDISK_TYPE can be used to
mention the preferred distro to build the ramdisk.
The supported types are: coreos, tinyipa and dib.
By default, lib/ironic will continue building coreos
based IPA ramdisk.

The environment variable IRONIC_DIB_RAMDISK_OPTIONS
specifies the options for disk-image-create command
and the platform on which to build the dib based
ironic-python-agent ramdisk.
Default value for IRONIC_DIB_RAMDISK_OPTIONS
is '-a amd64 ubuntu' when 'dib' is the selected distro.

Closes-Bug: 1510797

Change-Id: I0b7f45b87f92b739c0926f2de6c134f9d4e426bb

commit_message:
Add support for dib based agent ramdisk in lib/ironic

This commit adds support for building and configuring
dib based agent ramdisk for Ironic. The environment
variable IRONIC_RAMDISK_TYPE can be used to
mention the preferred distro to build the ramdisk.
The supported types are: coreos, tinyipa and dib.
By default, lib/ironic will continue building coreos
based IPA ramdisk.

The environment variable IRONIC_DIB_RAMDISK_OPTIONS
specifies the options for disk-image-create command
and the platform on which to build the dib based
ironic-python-agent ramdisk.
Default value for IRONIC_DIB_RAMDISK_OPTIONS
is 'ubuntu' when 'dib' is the selected distro.

This patch is required for iLO ThirdParty CI.

Closes-Bug: 1510797

Change-Id: I0b7f45b87f92b739c0926f2de6c134f9d4e426bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/79/264579/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The variable is used to mention the distro on which ironic-python-agent # ramdisk should be built on. The supported values now are "coreos", "ubuntu" # and "fedora". "coreos" ramdisk runs ironic-python-agent in a docker # container. "ubuntu" and "fedora" based ironic-python-agent ramdisk are # built using diskimage-builder. IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO=${IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO:-coreos} function build_ipa_ramdisk { local kernel_path=$1 local ramdisk_path=$2 if [ "$IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO" = "coreos" ]; then build_ipa_coreos_ramdisk $kernel_path $ramdisk_path elif [[ "$IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO" = "fedora" || "$IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO" = "ubuntu" ]]; then build_ipa_dib_ramdisk $kernel_path $ramdisk_path $IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO else die "IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO=$IRONIC_IPA_RAMDISK_DISTRO is not supported." fi } function build_ipa_coreos_ramdisk { echo "Building coreos ironic-python-agent deploy ramdisk"function build_ipa_dib_ramdisk { local kernel_path=$1 local ramdisk_path=$2 local distro=$3 local tempfile tempfile=$(mktemp --tmpdir=$DEST) echo "Building $distro ironic-python-agent deploy ramdisk" disk-image-create -a amd64 \ -o "$tempfile" \ "$distro" ironic-agent mv "${tempfile}.vmlinuz" "$kernel_path" mv "${tempfile}.initramfs" "$ramdisk_path" rm -f "$tempfile" } build_ipa_ramdisk $IRONIC_DEPLOY_KERNEL_PATH $IRONIC_DEPLOY_RAMDISK_PATH
deleted_lines: function build_ipa_coreos_ramdisk { echo "Building ironic-python-agent deploy ramdisk" build_ipa_coreos_ramdisk $IRONIC_DEPLOY_KERNEL_PATH $IRONIC_DEPLOY_RAMDISK_PATH

commit_message:
Make AggregateList.get_ return API & cell db items

Make the AggregateList get_all, get_by_hosts and get_by_metadata
functions return items from both the API and cell databases.

blueprint cells-aggregate-api-db

Change-Id: I0e1e11283e6ab2f7d2b976d126e914f9d7b4d8fb

commit_message:
Fix for OSD activation

We have a rare situation when after 'osd prepare' command marked osd
as active but actually it is not up. This patch activate OSD after each
time it is being prepared.

Change-Id: Ic0e60ed196f9b8f876fe002f171d27878bac55a0
Closes-Bug: 1573133

commit_message:
Configure Cinder backend sections for controllers

In case when Ceph role is not on controller, we have wrong cinder
configuration on controllers with wrong backend section name.

Change-Id: I9532b6d235ed80e7e62b5b04c0c98c993a21706f
Closes-bug: #1585115

commit_message:
Add boot information into the inventory

Adds a new BootInfo object with 2 fields:

* current_boot_mode - bios or uefi, detected from presence of /sys/firmware/efi
  as per the following answer: http://askubuntu.com/a/162896
  This field will be used for setting the boot_mode capability in ironic-inspector
* pxe_interface - PXE booting interface, if it can be detected.
  This fields is already used by ironic-inspector, added here for consistency.

Change-Id: Ib36b592ffaba3bfa055d65c9526607867d302584
Partial-Bug: #1571580

commit_message:
Composable Sahara services

Adds new puppet and puppet pacemaker specific services for Sahara API
and Sahara Engine.

The Pacemaker templates extend the default Sahara services and swap
in the pacemaker specific puppet-tripleo profile instead.

Change-Id: I1adda514e9592d149a3d45743a9a00b59c28ca38
Depends-On: I0c8bd68f9a98626e9d67ef713c72c9dd05b7cc12
Implements: blueprint composable-services-within-roles

added_lines: heat_template_version: 2016-04-08 description: > OpenStack Sahara Engine service configured with Puppet parameters: EndpointMap: default: {} description: Mapping of service endpoint -> protocol. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. type: json MysqlVirtualIPUri: type: string default: '' SaharaPassword: default: unset description: The password for the sahara service account, used by sahara-api. type: string hidden: true resources: SaharaBase: type: ./sahara-base.yaml outputs: role_data: description: Role data for the Sahara Engine role. value: config_settings: map_merge: - get_attr: [SaharaBase, role_data, config_settings] - sahara_dsn: &sahara_dsn list_join: - '' - - 'mysql+pymysql://sahara:' - {get_param: SaharaPassword} - '@' - {get_param: MysqlVirtualIPUri} - '/sahara' sahara::database_connection: *sahara_dsn sahara::db::mysql::password: {get_param: SaharaPassword} step_config: | include ::tripleo::profile::base::sahara::engine

commit_message:
Don't autoescape the templates

Autoescaping leads to rendered output like:

BuildRequires:  python-pbr >= 1.6

So ignore the bandit warning for now and add a unittest to check that
the output is valid.

Change-Id: I0834d5962d284baa2b439e925677af1f59ae2642

commit_message:
Add libvirt perf event

This blueprint is to add nova an ability to support perf event, these
event data can be collected by Ceilometer.

Co-authored-by: Alex Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>

Blueprint support-perf-event
Change-Id: I7cec5c583048134b1a7c3986428e32672434c3c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/13/319513/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== Libvirt: Support for perf event =============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-perf-event The purpose of this bluepring is to add an ability to use perf event to gain statistic (like cache usage) for each instance. Problem description =================== Perf event is a Linux feature that provides a framework for analyzing performance events at both hardware and software levels. Through a list of measurable events we can measure events coming from different sourcss (like context-switches, cache misses, etc.) and gain statistic for each instance. Use Cases ---------- A user is able to gain the last level cache usage of one instance through perf event. Proposed change =============== Add missing elements when generating XML definition in libvirt driver to support perf event. Add also a new flavor extra specs key to specify which perf event will be enabled for instance. The following is the new flavor extra specs key. * 'perf:events=<event list>' This indicates that which kinds of perf events will be used for instance. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Eli Qiao <qiaoliyong@gmail.com> Other contributors: qiaowei-ren Work Items ---------- The primary work items are * Add new flavor extra specs for perf event. * Update the libvirt guest XML configuration when one or more perf events are specified. Dependencies ============ And this spec will depend on the following libraries: * libvirt >= 1.3.3 Testing ======= Would need new unit tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Update the flavor section in admin guide. References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Approved. * - Newton - Re-introduced.

commit_message:
Add PUT support for generic container types

This adds the PUT command for modifying secret_refs in generic
containers. Non-generic containers still do not support PUT.
Three things :
1.Add update method to change information of the designated container
2.Add on_put method to handle PUT request. And only secret_refs can be
updated. So, a new JSON schema is written to meet it.
3.Provide some test cases to validate the secret_refs being updated.

APIImpact
Add PUT to update secret_refs in a generic container.

DocImpact
Co-Authored-By: Kevin Bishop <ktb2012@att.net>
Co-Authored-By: Chellygel <chelsea.winfree@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint api-containers-add-put
Change-Id: I23d9769776e204c151b5e17513eb10bf62fa0390
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/49/207249/25 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def update_container(self, container_ref, model=None, user_name=None): """Attempt to update a container. Only valid for generic containers. :param model: Metadata used to update the container :return: A tuple with the response and container ref resp = self.client.put(container_ref, request_model=model, user_name=user_name) returned_data = self.get_json(resp) container_ref = returned_data.get('container_ref') return resp, container_ref
deleted_lines: def update_container(self, container_ref, user_name=None): """Attempt to update a container (which is an invalid operation) :return: Response of the update. resp = self.client.put(container_ref, user_name=user_name) return resp

commit_message:
Credential Encryption

Support encryption of credentials in Keystone.

bp credential-encryption

Change-Id: I5896e4a4dd0f8d827d32751171fc86cd428f96bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/50/284950/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= Support Credential Encryption ============================= `bp credential-encryption <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/credential-encryption>`_ Support encryption of credentials in Keystone to avoid having them stored in plain text in the backend. Problem Description =================== Large organizations have security compliance that requires credentials to not be stored in plain text. Credentials in Keystone are currently being stored in the backend and are accessible to anyone with access to the backend. If a backend is compromised by an attacker they can easily get the credentials for any user. Also, anyone within an organization can look at the credentials in the backend bypassing any security access controls offered by Keystone. Proposed Change =============== Update the credentials driver to support encryption of the ``blob`` field in the ``credential`` table. Support having both encrypted and unencrypted ``blob`` fields for backwards compatibility. Optionally use Barbican to store credentials or encryption key. Alternatives ------------ None Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Encryption could decrease performance. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Users should not be forced to install Barbican as a Keystone requirement. Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: werner.mendizabal (Werner Mendizabal <nonameentername@gmail.com>) Work Items ---------- * None Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * None

commit_message:
Install libssl-dev and libffi-dev

On official ubuntu docker images, those libs are not
installed by default and are needed to compile the
python crypto modules.

Change-Id: If73529d2c1f3702ec55ea5520510eaef5016c1ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/43/318943/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ! $(dpkg -l libssl-dev &>/dev/null); then sudo -H apt-get -y install libssl-dev fi if ! $(dpkg -l libffi-dev &>/dev/null); then sudo -H apt-get -y install libffi-dev fi

subject: Use TinyIPA and iPXE for most Ironic jobs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-06 23:37:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/64cead276c4ddfad63c67333500988243d6b74f3', 'message': "Use TinyIPA and iPXE for most Ironic jobs

Unless there's a good reason to do otherwise, we want to use TinyIPA
(smaller ram footprint, faster boot times) and iPXE (uses http for all
transfers, reducing random failures due to network issues) for all
Ironic jobs.

With tinyipa being the default ramdisk for the Ironic tempest jobs, we
now gate IPA on both tinyipa and coreos ramdisks, to prevent breakage to
a single ramdisk being merged into IPA.

This follows the pattern expected of IPA->Ironic job interaction: IPA
gates on all possible supported ramdisks, then Ironic uses the one best
suited to CI to test all jobs, with IPA gate jobs ensuring that no
changes go in that break a single ramdisk.

Change-Id: Ib4cb2894b3894d7aff896e1dd49e3480253d94c9
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-11 00:02:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/bb59d3ca36af64a9236c5c90cf1964d8d1161c4a', 'message': "Use TinyIPA and iPXE for most Ironic jobs

Unless there's a good reason to do otherwise, we want to use TinyIPA
(smaller ram footprint, faster boot times) and iPXE (uses http for all
transfers, reducing random failures due to network issues) for all
Ironic jobs.

With tinyipa being the default ramdisk for the Ironic tempest jobs, we
now gate IPA on both tinyipa and coreos ramdisks, to prevent breakage to
a single ramdisk being merged into IPA.

This follows the pattern expected of IPA->Ironic job interaction: IPA
gates on all possible supported ramdisks, then Ironic uses the one best
suited to CI to test all jobs, with IPA gate jobs ensuring that no

commit_message:
Use TinyIPA and iPXE for most Ironic jobs

Unless there's a good reason to do otherwise, we want to use TinyIPA
(smaller ram footprint, faster boot times) and iPXE (uses http for all
transfers, reducing random failures due to network issues) for all
Ironic jobs.

With tinyipa being the default ramdisk for the Ironic tempest jobs, we
now gate IPA on both tinyipa and coreos ramdisks, to prevent breakage to
a single ramdisk being merged into IPA.

This follows the pattern expected of IPA->Ironic job interaction: IPA
gates on all possible supported ramdisks, then Ironic uses the one best
suited to CI to test all jobs, with IPA gate jobs ensuring that no
changes go in that break a single ramdisk.

Additionally, changes configuration to determine how large to make
devstack VMs based on ramdisk chosen.

Change-Id: Ib4cb2894b3894d7aff896e1dd49e3480253d94c9

commit_message:
zuul/puppet: bring back scenario003 on master

A previous commit dropped scenario003 from master, this patch aims to be
more specific and separate trusty & centos-7 rule so we bring back
scenario003 at the right place.

Change-Id: I88c6e5722c8a2ffe8d7315a23d92a54bc4c38873
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/27/324627/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # puppet-integration scenario003 was introduced after Liberty (OpenStack) but we stop to # test Trusty after Mitaka. - name: ^gate-puppet-openstack-integration-3-scenario003-tempest-ubuntu-trusty$ # puppet-integration scenario003 was introduced after Liberty (OpenStack). - name: ^gate-puppet-openstack-integration-3-scenario003-tempest-centos-7$ branch: ^(?!stable/(kilo|liberty)).*$
deleted_lines: # puppet-integration scenario003 was introduced after Liberty (OpenStack) - name: ^gate-puppet-openstack-integration-3-scenario003-tempest-(ubuntu-trusty|centos-7)$

commit_message:
crypto - remove default root secret

Make it a requirement that root_encryption_secret is
a minimum of 44 base64 encoded characters i.e. a minimum
of 32 bytes encoded to base 64.

This patch still has a default root_secret in the proxy
config.  This is just as temporary as the proxy config
having encryption middleware in the pipeline.  Without this,
functests would fail since devstack has no root secret defined.

Change-Id: I82d183f0b89bfd730578bb64623928bcbfaf657c

commit_message:
Fixed clean up process in confirm_resize() after resize/cold migration

On env with NUMA topology and enabled cpu pinning we have one problem.
If instance changes numa node (or even pinned cpus in numa node)
during cold migration from one host to another confirming resize
failed with "Cannot pin/unpin cpus from the following pinned set".

It happening because confirm_resize() tries to clean up source
host using numa topology from destination host.

Closes-Bug: #1585214

Change-Id: I3b87be3f25fc0bce4efd9804fa562a6f66355464

commit_message:
Allow domain admins to list users in groups with v3 policy

Domain admins (with a domain scoped token) could not list members of
groups in their domain or groups of a user in their domain.
This was due to 2 reasons: the v3 policy rule
'identity:list_groups_for_user' was not evaluating the users domain
and the identity controller method protections of 'list_users_in_group'
and 'list_groups_for_user' were not providing the required targets for
the rules.

Change-Id: Ibf8442a2ceefc2bb0941bd5e7beba6c252b2ab36
Closes-Bug: #1433402
Closes-Bug: #1458994

commit_message:
Allow deployment with pre-generated ssh keys and certificates

This patch is part of a series that will allow the deployment
of a simple multinode octavia devstack, where the certs and
ssh keys are uniform over all the controllers.

Orchestrating the deployment of the same ssh keys or certificates
becomes difficult without making use of tools like ansible otherwise.

The provided certificate is valid for 10 years.

Change-Id: I45e8e54d58a725281636a61fdb769265de50d9ba

commit_message:
[inspector] Update authentication parameters

Inspector has switched to keystoneauth and authentication plugins,
this change makes puppet-ironic use them. Also this change exposes
auth_strategy parameter disabling keystone support completely.

This change removes deprecation warnings on inspector start up.

Change-Id: Icb0948c3fc085c76c3309ab1ad194a978922bfdb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ironic refs/changes/46/323546/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*auth_strategy*] # (optional) API authentication strategy: keystone or noauth # Defaults to 'keystone' ## [*ironic_auth_type*] # (optional) Authentication plugin for accessing Ironic # Defaults to 'password' ## [*swift_auth_type*] # (optional) Authentication plugin for accessing Swift # Defaults to 'password' # $auth_strategy = 'keystone', $ironic_auth_type = 'password', $swift_auth_type = 'password', if $auth_strategy == 'keystone' { ironic_inspector_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_type': value => 'password'; 'keystone_authtoken/auth_uri': value => $auth_uri; 'keystone_authtoken/auth_url': value => $identity_uri; 'keystone_authtoken/username': value => $admin_user; 'keystone_authtoken/password': value => $admin_password, secret => true; 'keystone_authtoken/project_name': value => $admin_tenant_name; } } ironic_inspector_config { 'DEFAULT/auth_strategy': value => $auth_strategy; 'ironic/auth_type': value => $ironic_auth_type; 'ironic/username': value => $ironic_username; 'ironic/password': value => $ironic_password, secret => true; 'ironic/project_name': value => $ironic_tenant_name; 'ironic/auth_url': value => $ironic_auth_url; 'swift/auth_type': value => $swift_auth_type; 'swift/project_name': value => $swift_tenant_name; 'swift/auth_url': value => $swift_auth_url;

with "No Valid Host".

commit_message:
Add support for building ISO for deploy ramdisk

This commit adds support for building and uploading
an ISO image for deploy ramdisk.  This is used by
some drivers in Ironic today. A new variable
IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_REQUIRED=true can be set in localrc
to create and upload ISO image for the deploy ramdisk.

Closes-Bug: 1510914
Change-Id: I27ab9ab03f8af41cc3906f1ede9b85e5127c766f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/18/239918/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_REQUIRED=$(trueorfalse False IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_REQUIRED)function is_deploy_iso_required { [[ "$IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_REQUIRED" == "True" ]] && return 0 return 1 } local iso_path=$3 if is_deploy_iso_required; then imagebuild/coreos/iso-image-create -k $kernel_path -i $ramdisk_path -o $iso_path fi local image_create_args="$distro ironic-agent" if is_deploy_iso_required; then image_create_args+=" iso" fi $image_create_args local IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_PATH=$TOP_DIR/files/ir-deploy-$IRONIC_DEPLOY_DRIVER.iso local IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_PATH=$IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO # NOTE: Think of these variables from bash exit code perspective # iso_required = 0, if iso is required # iso_required = 1, if iso is not required # iso_exists = 0, if iso exists # iso_exists = 1, if iso doesn't exist iso_required=$(is_deploy_iso_required; echo $?) iso_exists=$(test -e $IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_PATH; echo $?) if [ ! -e "$IRONIC_DEPLOY_RAMDISK_PATH" -o \ ! -e "$IRONIC_DEPLOY_KERNEL_PATH" -o \ \( "$iso_required" = "0" -a "$iso_exists" = "1" \) ]; then build_ipa_ramdisk $IRONIC_DEPLOY_KERNEL_PATH $IRONIC_DEPLOY_RAMDISK_PATH $IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_PATH if is_deploy_iso_required; then IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_ID=$(openstack \ --os-token $token \ --os-url http://$GLANCE_HOSTPORT \ image create \ $(basename $IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_PATH) \ --public --disk-format=iso \ --container-format=bare \ < $IRONIC_DEPLOY_ISO_PATH | grep ' id ' | get_field 2)

commit_message:
Remove hdp 2.0.6 plugin

Newton release is opened, so we can remove this
plugin from sahara codebase

Implements blueprint: remove-hdp206
Change-Id: I1ebf90e716964151c88de53d127789251bef066b

commit_message:
Readable logging for Heat templates

Sahara used to write Heat template to log output in format
which cannot be parsed with JSON or YAML validation tools.
As a result it caused difficultis for a user to read the
initial template.

This issue is solved by making  Sahara write logs in json format.

Closes-bug: 1552239

Change-Id: Ie7a9f6fcad29899dd53fa43884e783c58ea304ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/38/305138/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copyfrom oslo_serialization import jsonutils as json log_kwargs = copy.deepcopy(kwargs) log_kwargs['template'] = yaml.safe_load(log_kwargs['template']) for i in log_kwargs['files'].keys(): log_kwargs['files'][i] = yaml.safe_load(log_kwargs['files'][i]) log_kwargs = json.dumps(log_kwargs) LOG.debug("Creating Heat stack with args: \n{args}" .format(args=log_kwargs)) LOG.debug("Updating Heat stack {stack} with args: \n" "{args}".format(stack=stack, args=log_kwargs))
deleted_lines: LOG.debug("Creating Heat stack with args: {args}" .format(args=kwargs)) LOG.debug("Updating Heat stack {stack} with args: " "{args}".format(stack=stack, args=kwargs))

commit_message:
[Verify][CI] Add 'ctx-create-resources' arg to rally_verify.py

The 'ctx-create-resources' arg was added to the rally_verify.py script
in accordance with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/310151/ .

Change-Id: Iba478166976619269ea7e442d95ee593534cd11c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/32/310232/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid help="Mode of job. The 'full' mode corresponds to the full set of " "Tempest tests. The 'light' mode corresponds to the smoke set " "of Tempest tests.", help="Launch 2 verifications and compare them.") parser.add_argument( "--ctx-create-resources", action="store_true", help="Delete all images and flavors, and also create a shared " "network before running verification to make Tempest context " "create images, flavors and network resources.") # If the 'ctx-create-resources' arg is provided, delete all images and # flavors, and also create a shared network to make Tempest context # create images, flavors and network resources. if args.ctx_create_resources: from rally.common import db from rally.common import objects from rally import osclients deployment_uuid = objects.Deployment.get("devstack")["uuid"] credentials = db.deployment_get(deployment_uuid)["admin"] clients = osclients.Clients(objects.Credential(**credentials)) LOG.info("Delete all images to make Tempest context create images.") for image in clients.glance().images.list(): clients.glance().images.delete(image.id) LOG.info("Delete all flavors to make Tempest context create flavors.") for flavor in clients.nova().flavors.list(): clients.nova().flavors.delete(flavor.id) LOG.info("Create a shared network to make Tempest context " "create network resources (network, subnet, router).") tenant_name = clients.keystone().tenant_name tenant_id = clients.keystone().get_project_id(tenant_name) net_body = { "network": { "name": "shared-net-%s" % str(uuid.uuid4()), "tenant_id": tenant_id, "shared": True } } clients.neutron().create_network(net_body)
deleted_lines: help="mode of job", help="Launch 2 verification and compare them.")

commit_message:
Add support for removing flavor-access

Add "--project" and "--project-domain" options in
"flavor unset" command to remove flavor access.

Change-Id: Ia5c5a80d9890d5af066b75b4e202647c18c7d915
Partial-Bug: #1575461

This can be used in case collisions between project names exist.

commit_message:
Fix section for secure_proxy_ssl_header

In Newton nova uses HTTPtoWSGI middleware
and secure_proxy_ssl_header is deprecated,
however in Mitaka secure_proxy_ssl_header is
still used, so its section is fixed by this commit.

Change-Id: Ic6ac9f61778f989ebbe5408b7e47176673ced427
Related-Bug: #1576740
Closes-Bug: #1588360

subject: Remove memoize that holds connections open
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-26 06:07:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/81403fd1baa51f7a937e76446457d1813334f1e4', 'message': 'Remove useless memoize that holds connections open

This memoize usage was not only useless (it was hashing
the request which changed for pretty much every request, so
never returned the cached result) but it also served to
hold on to connection objects for a very long time, resulting
in exhaustion of file descriptors.

commit_message:
Remove memoize that holds connections open

This memoize usage holds on to connection objects for a very long
time, resulting in exhaustion of file descriptors.

Change-Id: If7367819b050a65562b3e05175ab15bd93d0d398
Fixes-Bug: 1584109

commit_message:
Improve system info page

This change adds region info and all the url types,
and also removes enabled (which never did anything).

Change-Id: I7594d2b3d1e9826ec66bac379059171150155c4b
Closes-bug: #1497448

commit_message:
Fix babel msgids to include tag attributes and entities

The messages for translation were omitting the attributes in
tags and HTML entities embedded in the translation strings,
thus they no longer matched the original HTML.

Additionally, HTML entities are mostly (but not always) decoded
by the browser before angular-gettext sees them, so we have to
emulate this behaviour in our babel extractor so the message
ids match.

Change-Id: Ie6ae0776a2c0d7db589b34a9e7676508178a473d
Closes-Bug: 1561550
Closes-Bug: 1561738
Closes-Bug: 1561761
(cherry picked from commit fdf0bf6f186f056fea6ed5761616c40463a2e269)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/67/316767/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- encoding: UTF-8 -*-# browser innerHTML decodes some html entities automatically, so when # we extract the msgid and want to match what Javascript sees, we need # to leave some entities alone, but decode all the rest. Add entries # to HTML_ENTITIES as necessary. HTML_ENTITY_PASSTHROUGH = {'amp', 'gt', 'lt'} HTML_ENTITY_DECODED = { 'reg': u'®', 'times': u'×' } s = tag if attrs: s += ' ' + ' '.join('%s="%s"' % a for a in attrs) self.data += '<%s>' % s def handle_entityref(self, name): if self.in_translate: if name in HTML_ENTITY_PASSTHROUGH: self.data += '&%s;' % name else: self.data += HTML_ENTITY_DECODED[name] def handle_charref(self, name): if self.in_translate: self.data += '&#%s;' % name def handle_comment(self, comment): if self.in_translate: self.data += '<!--%s-->' % comment

commit_message:
Enable 'null' value for user_data in V2.1 API

The legacy v2 API allow the 'null' value for user_data. Unfortunately
the v2.1 API didn't match that in the input validation. This patch
enables 'null' value, at sametime, it enables for v2.1 compat mode
also.

Change-Id: Iae614035efd4b37c214754ad12b17ca224b8fd92
Closes-Bug: #1582911
(cherry picked from commit 22c87390a33300b93f0913d4e787662b119a00b9)
(cherry picked from commit 2024387ecc0922abe97863c349cf94df1d4462d0)

commit_message:
Add aggregates tables to the API db.

CellsV2 requires that aggregates be available in the API db. Create
the 'aggregates', 'aggregate_metadata' and 'aggregate_hosts' tables in the
API db.

blueprint cells-aggregate-api-db

Change-Id: I19fa3a28181831c5cd7b19cd2a5a2ea0d40e45f8

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova.db.sqlalchemy import api_models from nova.db.sqlalchemy import models from nova import test class AggregateTablesCompareTestCase(test.NoDBTestCase): def _get_columns_list(self, model): columns_list = [m.key for m in model.__table__.columns] return columns_list def _check_column_list(self, columns_new, columns_old, added=[], removed=[]): for c in added: columns_new.remove(c) for c in removed: columns_old.remove(c) intersect = set(columns_new).intersection(set(columns_old)) if intersect != set(columns_new) or intersect != set(columns_old): return False return True def _compare_models(self, m_a, m_b, added=[], removed=['deleted_at', 'deleted']): c_a = self._get_columns_list(m_a) c_b = self._get_columns_list(m_b) self.assertTrue(self._check_column_list(c_a, c_b, added=added, removed=removed)) def test_tables_aggregate_metadata(self): self._compare_models(api_models.AggregateMetadata(), models.AggregateMetadata()) def test_tables_aggregates(self): self._compare_models(api_models.Aggregate(), models.Aggregate())

commit_message:
Enable 'null' value for user_data in V2.1 API

The legacy v2 API allow the 'null' value for user_data. Unfortunately
the v2.1 API didn't match that in the input validation. This patch
enables 'null' value, at sametime, it enables for v2.1 compat mode
also.

Conflicts:
        api-ref/source/parameters.yaml

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to the api-ref parameters file
not existing until Newton. It's just a note in the docs on the
user_data parameter and isn't required for this backport.

Change-Id: Iae614035efd4b37c214754ad12b17ca224b8fd92
Closes-Bug: #1582911
(cherry picked from commit 22c87390a33300b93f0913d4e787662b119a00b9)

commit_message:
Merge StorletInvocationXXXProtocol

Now we have some StorletInvocationXXXProtocol casses, which
are not so different.
This patch merges these classes into base one, and makes
InvocationProtocol's function more general.

Change-Id: Ie7ef1b6f5f475898191d3bec5325dc39ab370e0f

commit_message:
layout: cleanup redundant rules

In zuul/layout, we already have:
  - name: ^gate-(puppet-.*-(syntax|unit|beaker|integration)-|tripleo-ci-f22-).*$
    skip-if:
      - project: ^openstack/puppet-.*$
        all-files-match-any:
          - ^.*\.md$
          - ^releasenotes/.*$

It was redundant with what is removed in this patch.

Change-Id: I85685c7ea5b257e44e274aa7a41ff0305ecb05dc

commit_message:
Remove kilo bitrot job definition and usage

Kilo is EOL, this change removes the bitrot job
definitions and usage from the projects using it.

There are a few in here that aren't managed by the
stable-maint-team for the final kilo release, like
manila, murano, zaqar and the neutron-*aas projects,
but we can't speak for the state of their kilo branch
at this point anyway, and they just need to end of life
the branch after tagging it.

Change-Id: I46fb0305bd0187eae2a81828916e9f946f60f1e1

commit_message:
Microversion 2.28 changes cpu_info string to JSON object

After this microversion Nova API the GET request to
/v2.1/os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_id} responses cpu_info
as regular JSON object instead of string.

Implements blueprint nova-api-hypervsor-cpu-info

Change-Id: I14db9017f69e70e759cc80d031f76af8be179e45

commit_message:
Setup OSA os_designate core group

This patch implements a core group for the
openstack-ansible-os_designate repository in order to allow a
service specific set of core reviewers to be added to it.

The openstack-ansible-core team retains its previous voting
capabilities.

Change-Id: Ia8268788a847c75aa92e6e69ddeebdf367e49a0a

subject: api: do not log a traceback if error is not expected
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-01 08:09:34.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_db/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/2938f28ca7a75a46068d2cc03f46fa2e7f30aadc', 'message': 'api: do not log a traceback if error is not expected

Currently, when using the retry decorator on a function that raises an error on
the last retry, oslo.db always log the following:

ERROR oslo_db.api [-] DB exceeded retry limit.
ERROR oslo_db.api Traceback (most recent call last):
ERROR oslo_db.api File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oslo_db/api.py", line 138, in wrapper
ERROR oslo_db.api return f(*args, **kwargs)
ERROR oslo_db.api File "/opt/stack/gnocchi/gnocchi/indexer/sqlalchemy.py", line 686, in list_resources
ERROR oslo_db.api raise indexer.InvalidPagination("Invalid sort keys")
ERROR oslo_db.api InvalidPagination: Invalid pagination: `Invalid sort keys'

Which is wrong, since in this case the `InvalidPagination' is totally unrelated to the retry code.

This patch fixes that by only calling LOG.exception if the last try is really
about an expected retry condition.

Change-Id: Iacc6d3aeac41ddfff76f081428678e2e0688055a
Closes-Bug: #1587637
'}]
commit_message:
api: do not log a traceback if error is not expected

Currently, when using the retry decorator on a function that raises an error on
the last retry, oslo.db always log the following:

ERROR oslo_db.api [-] DB exceeded retry limit.
ERROR oslo_db.api Traceback (most recent call last):
ERROR oslo_db.api File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oslo_db/api.py", line 138, in wrapper
ERROR oslo_db.api return f(*args, **kwargs)
ERROR oslo_db.api File "/opt/stack/gnocchi/gnocchi/indexer/sqlalchemy.py", line 686, in list_resources
ERROR oslo_db.api raise indexer.InvalidPagination("Invalid sort keys")
ERROR oslo_db.api InvalidPagination: Invalid pagination: `Invalid sort keys'

Which is wrong, since in this case the `InvalidPagination' is totally unrelated to the retry code.

This patch fixes that by only calling LOG.exception if the last try is really
about an expected retry condition.

Change-Id: Iacc6d3aeac41ddfff76f081428678e2e0688055a
Closes-Bug: #1587637
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/14/323714/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: expected = self._is_exception_expected(e) if remaining > 0: ectxt.reraise = not expected else: if expected: LOG.exception(_LE('DB exceeded retry limit.'))
deleted_lines: if remaining > 0: ectxt.reraise = not self._is_exception_expected(e) else: LOG.exception(_LE('DB exceeded retry limit.'))

Add fix for hardware.cpu.util meter in sd-strategy

since the values that comes from ceilometer hardware.cpu.util
are already normalized.

commit_message:
Allow to configure container_sync middleware

Add possibility to configure container_sync middleware. Also
allow to configure swift container-sync-realms, which specifying
the allowable clusters and their information, which is required
for container_sync.

Change-Id: I183841cca3daf72a30db160b88c9e3a9335ad7dc
(cherry picked from commit ec4db849c8840a9203bdf023c22ff0d208f5a801)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/09/323409/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #### swift_container_sync_realms_config Same as `swift_config`, but path is `/etc/swift/container-sync-realms.conf' Use this file for specifying the allowable clusters and their information. ```puppet swift_container_sync_realms_config { 'realm1/cluster_clustername1': value => 'https://host1/v1/' } ```

commit_message:
Fix missing bool haproxy_use_keepalived

When running an AIO install from master, the haproxy-install.yml play
fails with the following error:

fatal: [aio1] => error while evaluating conditional: \
haproxy_use_keepalived|bool and inventory_hostname in \
groups['haproxy'][0]

This is because the variable haproxy_use_keepalived is undefined.

Change-Id: I33565fdb2418a6ec363b36add7e3d39a1433ad9c
Closes-Bug: #1568977
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/31/304231/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: haproxy_use_keepalived: False

subject: Libvirt: Use the virtlogd deamon
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-13 15:28:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/a1416e5cf6f68e63078ef144bf16ff79b1b9d7da', 'message': 'Libvirt: Use the virtlogd deamon for logs

If the *serial console* feature is enabled on a compute node with
``[serial_console].enabled = True`` it deactivates the logging of the
boot messages. From a REST API perspective, this means that the two
APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole`` are mutually
exclusive. Both APIs can be valuable for cloud operators in the case
when something goes wrong during the launch of an instance. This
blueprint wants to lift the XOR relationship between those two REST
APIs.

Change-Id: I9a1fbf005b0f48df90093a346579d9ddc64f7846
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-11-10 16:07:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/5dd5e11f3e3214c3b40d58b7ac18328b1391454c', 'message': 'Libvirt: Use the virtlogd deamon for logs

``[serial_console].enabled = True`` it deactivates the logging of the
boot messages. From a REST API perspective, this means that the two
APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole`` are mutually
exclusive. Both APIs can be valuable for cloud operators in the case
when something goes wrong during the launch of an instance. This
blueprint wants to lift the XOR relationship between those two REST
APIs.

Change-Id: I9a1fbf005b0f48df90093a346579d9ddc64f7846
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-11-11 17:06:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/b773a98100d54c77817b4e5eae412399044724c8', 'message': 'Libvirt: Use the virtlogd deamon for logs

If the *serial console* feature is enabled on a compute node with
``[serial_console].enabled = True`` it deactivates the logging of the

commit_message:
Libvirt: Use the virtlogd deamon

If the *serial console* feature is enabled on a compute node with
``[serial_console].enabled = True`` it deactivates the logging of the
boot messages. From a REST API perspective, this means that the two
APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole`` are mutually
exclusive. Both APIs can be valuable for cloud operators in the case
when something goes wrong during the launch of an instance. This
blueprint wants to lift the XOR relationship between those two REST
APIs.

blueprint libvirt-virtlogd

Change-Id: I9a1fbf005b0f48df90093a346579d9ddc64f7846
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/91/234291/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================= Libvirt: Use the virtlogd deamon for logs ========================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-virtlogd If the *serial console* feature is enabled on a compute node with ``[serial_console].enabled = True`` it deactivates the logging of the boot messages. From a REST API perspective, this means that the two APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole`` are mutually exclusive. Both APIs can be valuable for cloud operators in the case when something goes wrong during the launch of an instance. This blueprint wants to lift the XOR relationship between those two REST APIs. Problem description =================== The problem can be seen in the method ``_create_serial_console_devices`` in the libvirt driver. The simplified logic is:: def _create_serial_console_devices(self, guest, instance, flavor, image_meta): if CONF.serial_console.enabled: console = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestSerial() console.type = "tcp" guest.add_device(console) else: consolelog = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestSerial() consolelog.type = "file" guest.add_device(consolelog) This ``if-else`` establishes the XOR relationship between having a log of the guest's boot messages or getting a handle to the guest's serial console. From a driver point of view, this means getting valid return values for the method ``get_serial_console`` or ``get_console_output`` which are used to satisfy the two REST APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole``. Use Cases ---------- From an end user point of view, this means that, with the current state, it is possible to get the console output of an instance on host A (serial console is not enabled) but after a rebuild on host B (serial console is enabled) it is not possible to get the console output. As an end user is not aware of the host's configuration, this could be a confusing experience. Written that down I'm wondering why the serial console was designed with a compute node scope and not with an instance scope, but that's another discussion I don't want to do here. After the implementation, deployers will have both means by hand if there is something wrong during the launch of an instance. The persisted log in case the instance crashed AND the serial console in case the instance launched but has issues, for example a failed establishing of networking so that SSH access is not possible. Also, they will be impacted with a new dependency on the hosts (see `Dependencies`_). Developers won't be impacted. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== I'd like to switch from the log file to the ``virtlogd`` deamon. This logging deamon was announced on the libvirt ML [1] and is not yet available but it could be exploitable during the Mitaka cycle and for the rest of this document I assume that this will be the case. This logging deamon handles the output from the guest's console and writes it into the file ``/var/log/virtlogd/qemu/$GUEST.log`` on the host but truncates/rotates that log so that it doesn't exhaust the hosts disk space (this would solve an old bug [3]. This log file can be fetched and used as content for the ``get_console_output`` method. Open Questions -------------- A few open questions I couldn't answer myself because I couldn't do a PoC because the *virtlogd* isn't available yet. I hope to answer them as soon as the *virtlogd* is available. #. How is the migration/rebuild handled? The 4 cases which are possible (based on the node's patch level): #. ``N -> N``: Neither source nor target node is patched. That's what we have today. Nothing to do. #. ``N -> N+1``: The target node is patched, which means it can make use of the output from *virtlogd*. Can we "import" the existing log of the source node into the *virtlogd* logs of the target node? #. ``N+1 -> N``: The source node is patched and the instance gets migrated to a target node which cannot utilize the *virtlogd* output. If the serial console is enable on the target node, do we throw away the log because we cannot update it on the target node? #. ``N+1 -> N+1``: Source and target node are patched. Will libvirt migrate the existing log from the source node too, which would solve another open bug [4]. #. Could a stalling of the guest happen if *nova-compute* is reading the log file and *virtlogd* tries to write to the file but is blocked? #. IIUC the *virtlogd* deamon has a ``1:1`` relationship to a compute node. It would be interesting how well it performs when, for example, hundreds of instances are running on one compute node. #. Are there architecture dependencies? Right now, a nova-compute node on a s390 architecture depends on the *serial console* feature because it cannot provide the other console types (VNC, SPICE, RDP). Which means it would benefit from having both. #. How are restarts of the *virtlogd* deamon handled? Do we lose information in the timeframe between stop and start? #. Do we need a version check of libvirt to detect if the *virtlodg* is available on the host? Or is it sufficient to check if the folder ``/var/log/virtlogd/`` is present? Alternatives ------------ #. In case where the *serial console* is enabled, we could establish a connection to the guest with it and execute ``tail /var/log/dmesg.log`` and return that output in the driver's ``get_console_output`` method which is used to satisfy the ``os-getConsoleOutput`` REST API. **Counter-arguments:** We would need to save the authentication data to the guest, which would not be technically challenging but the customers could be unhappy that Nova can access their guests at any time. A second argument is, that the serial console access is blocking, which means if user A uses the serial console of an instance, user B is not able to do the same. #. We could remove the ``if-else`` and create both devices. **Counter-arguments:** This was tried in [2] and stopped because this could introduce a backwards incompatibility which could prevent the rebuild of an instance. The root cause for this was, that there is an upper bound of 4 serial devices on a guest, and this upper bound could be exceeded if an instance which already has 4 serial devices gets rebuilt on a compute node which would have patch [2]. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Markus Zoeller (https://launchpad.net/~mzoeller) Work Items ---------- * get a gate job running which has the *serial console* activated? Dependencies ============ * the *libvirt virtlod logging deamon* described in [1]. Testing ======= The tempest tests which are annotated with ``CONF.compute_feature_enabled.console_output`` will have to work with a setup which * has the dependency to the *virtlogd deamon* resolved. * AND has the serial console feature enabled (AFAIK there is not job right now which has this enabled) Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1] libvirt ML, "[libvirt] RFC: Building a virtlogd daemon": http://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2015-January/msg00762.html [2] Gerrit; "libvirt: use log file and serial console at the same time": https://review.openstack.org/#/c/188058/ [3] Launchpad; " console.log grows indefinitely ": https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/832507 [4] Launchpad; "live block migration results in loss of console log": https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1203193 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
[inspector] create a separate class for configuring logging

Also makes the default log directory /var/log/ironic-inspector.

NOTE:
    This change differs from the Mitaka one as it used explicit default values
    for all parameters.

Change-Id: If243d78ce16d43135533cd61526172948d2f6ede
(cherry picked from commit 794d9c1a84f68bdfb27d13adaa8ec62d686d7549)

commit_message:
Move evaluation_interval and older_than to engine

The evaluation_interval and older_than settings apply
to the Mistral engine process (not executor). So it makes
sense to manage them within engine.pp.

Change-Id: I79ffd637ebb8094c27f42270b2c14ee77c861297

commit_message:
Update keystone wsgi scripts

This change updates the wsgi configuration for keystone to use the
keystone-wsgi-public and keystone-wsgi-admin scripts provided. The
previous httpd.py implementation has been deprecated as part of the
Mitaka cycle. We are deprecating the previous single script variable
that was used for both endpoints infavor of two new variables for each
of the scripts.

Change-Id: I03a7a057cae0bf86331191faf47ec394487150a7
Closes-Bug: #1558290
(cherry picked from commit e812075fd9ed7c0754e00adaf74db6eeaf403bc1)

commit_message:
Use upper-constraints.txt file for all tox targets

The only targets that are left unconstrained are those that belong to
post merge queues where constraints are not yet available.

Change-Id: I0546be87a0bb2a34b8c030d883ede3c45e6d6f54

subject: Don't set html_last_updated_fmt without git
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-13 07:22:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler/commit/cfe71be4e4258bdee0686b81c392d2ef3edc00d0', 'message': 'Don't set html_last_updated_fmt without git

Using a timestamp as value for "html_last_updated_fmt" isn't good
for the reproducible builds initiative from different downstream
distributions because the build result always differs due to the
timestamp in the documentation.

commit_message:
Don't set html_last_updated_fmt without git

Using a timestamp as value for "html_last_updated_fmt" isn't good
for the reproducible builds initiative from different downstream
distributions because the build result always differs due to the
timestamp in the documentation.
Also when not setting "html_last_updated_fmt", the value can be set
via command line when running "sphinx-build -D".

Change-Id: Ia23451e6b53f6f83dd22e069ef42a4a067ec5881
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler refs/changes/03/305003/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add Port and Chassis logical name

This spec is mostly copied from Node logical name.

Change-Id: I2cfea4e467654904af7822a01438e45b8441200a
Partial-bug: #1534893
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/82/295082/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Port and Chassis Logical Names ============================== https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1534893 Everything except node in Ironic is tracked via UUID. This isn't very friendly to humans. We should support ports chassises being referenced by a logical name. Problem description =================== Operators, and other humans, that use Ironic find it awkward and error-prone to use UUIDs to refer to entities that are tracked by Ironic. However computers, and extremely geekly people, prefer to track things by the canonical identifier - the UUID. While humans are more likely to use the command-line tools, computers are more likely to use the REST API. However the opposite is also true, consequently both the API and command-line client require updating to support logical names. It's useful to be able to assign semantic meaning to ports - for example the physical ethernet name to assist operators in managing ports in their network. The semantic identifier of a chassis can contain some BMC information which may help to manage nodes. Proposed change =============== We propose adding a new <logical name> to ports and chassises like nodes, which can be used interchangeably with the <port/chassis uuid>. Everywhere a <uuid> can be specified, we should be able to instead specify a <logical name>. This should be the case for the REST API and python-ironicclient. At the REST API level, the mechanisms to set/retrieve port/chassis fields will be used to set/retrieve the logical name for a port/chassis. At the python-ironiclient level, support will be added to manage associations between a port/chassis and a <logical-name>. See further details below. Where a change in the interface is required, such as a new attribute on an object, a new key in a dictionary, or a new field in POST data, the <logical name> will be referred to as "name" (unless that is already used). This is for consistency with other OpenStack APIs. Alternatives ------------ For chassis, we can use description instead. Data model impact ----------------- There should be a 1:1 mapping between a <logical name> and a <uuid>. We can consider a <logical name> as an alias for a <uuid>. When the version of ironic that includes these changes is run against an existing installation, the database will be upgraded to support the addition of the <logical name> field to the port/chassis object. The association between logical-name and UUID will need to be stored as a new attribute on the port/chassis object. In the case where no logical name has been set, this field will be None. What is a logical name? ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This change introduces the concept of a <logical name> to ironic so that a human readable name can be associated with ports/chasises. This <logical name> should be hostname safe, that is, the node logical name should also be usable as the hostname for the instance. For this to be true, the following references should be used to define what is a valid <logical name>: [wikipedia:hostname], [RFC952] and [RFC1123]. In simple english, what this means is that <logical names>s can be between 1 and 63 characters long, with the valid characters being [a-z0-9] and '-', except that a <logical name> cannot begin or end with a '-'. As a regular expression, this can be represented as: <logical name> == [a-z0-9]([a-z0-9\-]{0,61}[a-z0-9]|[a-z0-9]{0,62})? Note: It is recognised that a valid <logical name> could also be a valid <node uuid>, which could lead to confusion. As a consequence, logical names will be rejected as invalid if they are valid UUIDs. State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- A number of existing APIs will need to be modified to support the use of <logical_name>. The following APIs will add in a new response body field named "name": * GET /v1/ports * POST /v1/ports * PATCH /v1/ports * GET /v1/chassis * POST /v1/chassis * PATCH /v1/chassis The following APIs will reflect the existing uuid version of this API, along with adding support to specify logical_name instead of uuid in the URL: * GET /v1/ports/(port_logical_name) * PATCH /v1/ports/(port_logical_name) * DELETE /v1/ports/(port_logical_name) * GET /v1/chassis/(chassis_logical_name) * PATCH /v1/chassis/(chassis_logical_name) * DELETE /v1/chassis/(chassis_logical_name) RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ This change as specified here is wholly contained with ironic itself. It is most probably beneficial to expose the concept of a logical name to outside ironic for use in the Nova API. If required, this will be addressed in an independent spec. Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- If Horizon or Ironic-UI allows a user to enter a port/chassis UUID, and validates it as conforming to a particular regex, then this will most likely require change to support either a <uuid> or <logical name>. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- In each sub-command in python-ironicclient where a port/chassis UIUD can be specified, we will need to be able to support a logical name in its place. Please see the detailed changes in the REST API section for an idea of the scope of change required. Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: niu-zglinux Work Items ---------- 1. DB and object modifications 2. REST API additions and modifications 3. python-ironicclient additions and modifications Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit testing will be sufficient to verify the veracity of this change Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== As mentioned above, when the code that includes this change is run against a previous Ironic install that does not have this change, the database will need to have it's schema updated to add in the additional field 'name'. Documentation Impact ==================== Online documentation for both the Ironic API and python-ironicclient will need to be updated to accompany this change. References ========== This spec is mostly copied from the node logical name spec. (ref https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/kilo-implemented/logical-names.html) * [wikipedia:hostname] - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hostname * [RFC952] - http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc952 * [RFC1123] - http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1123

commit_message:
Remove unused and wrong pot file

We do not store pot files in repositories anymore, remove it.

Note: This repository is not translated at all and the setup is even
wrong (wrong name monasca instead of monasca_api). Once you setup the
repo for creation, this change will be needed as well.

Change-Id: Iddfd990f97c39519bffa09eeaa1404ae361126db

commit_message:
neutron_sync_mode not honored when syncing ACLs

The OVN neutron_sync_mode configuration option is not honored
when syncing ACLs. This problem impacts both service startup
and the neutron_ovn_db_sync command-line utility.

When neutron_sync_mode is set to 'log', ACLs will be synced.
The syncing should only occur when neutron_sync_mode is set
to 'repair'.

Change-Id: I0f0b703a4a3bae6d398978fa33da61fc5f2e2106
Closes-Bug: #1586053

commit_message:
Add OVN NB sync support for ML2

Add OVN NB sync support for ML2. The OVN NB synchronizer
was update to support ML2 while maintaining the core plugin
support. TODOs were added to the code for items to handle
when the core plugin is removed.

The OVN NB synchronizer also works from the command line tool.

This patch set also fixes router sync to only apply when
OVN L3 is enabled.

Change-Id: I9d16301c3f85586def78898545a57c9a74a1594c
Partial-Bug: #1578198
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/59/321059/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from networking_ovn import ovn_nb_sync if trigger.im_class == ovsdb_monitor.OvnWorker: # Call the synchronization task if its ovn worker # This sync neutron DB to OVN-NB DB only in inconsistent states self.synchronizer = ovn_nb_sync.OvnNbSynchronizer( self._plugin, self._ovn, config.get_ovn_neutron_sync_mode(), self ) self.synchronizer.sync()
deleted_lines: # TODO(rtheis): Synchronizer needs to use ML2 ... # if trigger.im_class == ovsdb_monitor.OvnWorker: # # Call the synchronization task if its ovn worker # # This sync neutron DB to OVN-NB DB only in inconsistent states # self.synchronizer = ovn_nb_sync.OvnNbSynchronizer( # self, self._ovn, config.get_ovn_neutron_sync_mode()) # self.synchronizer.sync()

commit_message:
Fix Bug #1583539 - rpm part

Install required development packages for openssl and ffi support using
the yum package manager. This should be applied as a complement of the
patch proposed at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318943/ which handles
the apt package manager.

Partial-Bug: 1583539

commit_message:
Enable arrow-parens

Arrow functions can omit parentheses when they have exactly one
parameter. In all other cases the parameter(s) must be wrapped
in parentheses. This rule enforces the consistent use of
parentheses in arrow functions.

http://eslint.org/docs/rules/arrow-parens

Change-Id: I40fca3fc2ecaf99ebb8ab9c40e7eaed8e78bdbd7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/eslint-config-openstack refs/changes/41/315641/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: arrow-parens: 2

commit_message:
Actions guideline

Change-Id: I7e61fff8f5efaada5cae0c48d6acb26613e4cfc3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/94/234994/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _actions: Actions ======= A common need of OpenStack APIs is to enable clients to trigger actions, with the most obvious example being the ability to start, stop or reboot instances. This document provides guidelines on how resources can expose their actions at the API level in a way that is consistent with REST principles. REST and actions: How *not* to do it ------------------------------------ The first inclination when implementing actions in an API is to expose these as appendices to the resource URL. For example, the action of rebooting a server instance is often represented by a request sent to URL *http://example.com/api/servers/123/reboot*. While this is a common technique, it conflicts with the REST principles in several ways: - REST requires that all URLs exposed by an API map to actual resources. - The abuse of actions in URLs converts the API into a procedural API, more in line with RPC architectures such as SOAP. - Since the HTTP methods map directly to CRUD resource operations, there is no clear choice of method to use to trigger an action. - An API with a large number of actions implemented with this technique expose a complicated, polluted URL namespace that makes it very difficult to implement hypermedia. - Clients are forced to hardcode all these actions, increasing client/server coupling. For all the above reasons, the inclusion of actions in URLs is strongly discouraged. Actions as Resources -------------------- The implementation proposed by this guideline considers actions first-class resources. As such, actions can be created, inspected, modified and deleted, like any other resource. The following sections describe the different aspects of the action resource implementation in detail. Resource URLs ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A resource that wishes to provide actions must expose an "actions" endpoint. For example, a server with a resource URL of *http://example.com/api/servers/123* can expose an actions endpoint on URL *http://example.com/api/servers/123/actions*. Note that the actions endpoint is a generic endpoint that will be used for all the actions that can be requested on the resource. Do not define a specific endpoint for each individual action supported by the resource. Representations ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The resource representation for an action resource has the following structure:: { "name": "<action_name>", "args": { "<arg1_name>": ""<arg1_value>"", "<arg2_name>": ""<arg2_value>"", ... } } When retrieving an action resource, the server can insert optional read-only attributes in the representation that provide status to the client:: { "name": "<action_name>", "args": { "<arg1_name>": ""<arg1_value>"", "<arg2_name>": ""<arg2_value>"", ... }, "started_at": <timestamp>, "ended_at": <timestamp_or_null>, "status": "in_progress|completed|failed" } HTTP Methods ~~~~~~~~~~~~ To trigger an action, a corresponding action resource must be created. This is accomplished with a ``POST`` request to the actions resource URL. For example, the following request reboots a server:: POST /servers/123/actions { "name": "reboot", "args": {} } If the action is started successfully, the server must respond with a 201 status code and include a ``Location`` header with the unique URL of the action resource that the client can query for status on the action. In the example above, this URL would have the form */servers/<server_id>/actions/<action_id>*. For APIs that wish to use a simpler implementation that does not require the use of individual action resources, the response can be 200 or 202 for synchronous or asynchronous actions respectively. In the case of an asynchronous action, it is assumed that the client can obtain status by querying the parent resource. The remaining HTTP methods are considered optional, and only make sense when the API implements individual action resource URLs. A ``GET`` request to the actions collection URL can be implemented to give clients the ability to obtain the action history on a resource. A ``GET`` resource sent to an individual action URL will return only the representation for that action. A ``DELETE`` request can be sent to an individual action URL to request the cancellation of an action currently in progress. A ``PUT`` request can be sent to an individual action URL to update the arguments of the action.

commit_message:
Enable no-this-before-super

In the constructor of derived classes, if this/super are used
before super() calls, it raises a reference error.

http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-this-before-super

Change-Id: I7cd9f2e802dbc1b3e9e91ca708366cb2b461e7fb

Constructors of derived classes must call super().

Change-Id: Ic5fd761584770bdd2ae1a361b85ccb0a0167fce3

commit_message:
Enable constructor-super

This rule checks usage of super() calls in class constructors.
Constructors of derived classes must call super().
Constructors of non derived classes must not call super().
If this is not observed, the javascript engine will raise
a runtime error.

http://eslint.org/docs/rules/constructor-super

Change-Id: Ic5fd761584770bdd2ae1a361b85ccb0a0167fce3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/eslint-config-openstack refs/changes/83/315183/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: constructor-super: 2

commit_message:
Update devstack dashboard+client clone+install method

This updates our devstack plugin to use the current clone+install
method for the client (missing vars) and dashboard (replaced with
the new method).

Designate itself is still using old vars, but I suspect this is
a leftover and there's really no need for Designate to try
clone itself since the plugin is inline now...

Change-Id: I2189abc196d74520fa3fae0da215a1c6dd891387
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/03/317003/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Catch all exceptions in PM's call to get_pool()

Unhandled exceptions in central, during PM start, can cause PM to fail. For
example, if pool managers called to central.get_pool() fails with, say an
OperationalError: (2013, 'Lost connection to MySQL server during query'),
then PM will crash out.

Change-Id: If076c451e8f9802a24f75d103dece8d1bf06af87
Closes-Bug: 1583982

added_lines: #################### # Header Variables # #################### x-auth-all-projects: description: | If enabled this will show results from all projects in Designate in: header required: false type: bool x-auth-sudo-project-id: description: | This allows a user to impersonate another project in: header required: false type: string x-auth-token: description: | Token used to identify the user from keystone in: header required: false type: string x-designate-edit-managed-records: description: | If enabled this will all users to edit records flagged as managed in: header required: false type: bool x-openstack-request-id: description: | ID of the request in: header required: false type: string zone_export_accepts: description: > Content-Type that will be accepted by the client. This endpoint will send a response with a ``text/dns`` content-type. If the client does not include a ``Accepts: text/dns`` header in: header required: true type: string #################### # Path Variables # #################### path_pool_id: description: | ID for this pool in: path required: true type: uuid path_recordset_id: description: | ID for the recordset in: path required: true type: uuid path_zone_id: description: | ID for the zone in: path required: true type: uuid path_zone_export_id: description: | ID for this zone export in: path required: true type: uuid path_zone_import_id: description: | ID for this zone import in: path required: true type: uuid path_zone_transfer_accept_id: description: | ID for this zone transfer accept in: path required: true type: uuid path_zone_transfer_request_id: description: | ID for this zone transfer request in: path required: true type: uuid tld_id: description: | ID for this tld in: path required: true type: uuid tsigkey_id: description: | ID for this tsigkey in: path required: true type: uuid #################### # Query Variables # #################### limit: description: | Requests a page size of items. Returns a number of items up to a limit value. Use the ``limit`` parameter to make an initial limited request and use the ID of the last-seen item from the response as the ``marker`` parameter value in a subsequent limited request. in: query required: false type: integer marker: description: | The ID of the last-seen item. Use the ``limit`` parameter to make an initial limited request and use the ID of the last-seen item from the response as the ``marker`` parameter value in a subsequent limited request. in: query required: false type: string recordset_data_filter: description: | Filter results to only show recordsets that have a record with data matching the filter in: query required: false type: string recordset_description_filter: description: | Filter results to only show recordsets that have a description matching the filter in: query required: false type: string recordset_name_filter: description: | Filter results to only show recordsets that have a name matching the filter in: query required: false type: string recordset_status_filter: description: | Filter results to only show recordsets that have a status matching the filter in: query required: false type: string recordset_ttl_filter: description: | Filter results to only show recordsets that have a ttl matching the filter in: query required: false type: string recordset_type_filter: description: | Filter results to only show recordsets that have a type matching the filter in: query required: false type: string sort_dir: description: | Sorts the response by the requested sort direction. A valid value is ``asc`` (ascending) or ``desc`` (descending). Default is ``asc``. You can specify multiple pairs of sort key and sort direction query parameters. If you omit the sort direction in a pair, the API uses the natural sorting direction of the server attribute that is provided as the ``sort_key``. in: query required: false type: string sort_key: description: | Sorts the response by the this attribute value. Default is ``id``. You can specify multiple pairs of sort key and sort direction query parameters. commit_message:
Process failure of cluster settings reset

Fuel UI should show a user-friendly message
with an appropriate instructions, if resetting
of cluster settings failed.

Closes-Bug: #1587868

commit_message:
Make booleans in templates explicit

We had several places in templates where booleans weren't
handled correctly - if the boolean was defined, the template
conditional would be true regardless of its value. Fix these
conditionals so they have the correct result when variables
are defined but false.

Change-Id: I2c8e0b8ac72b5a132b0d3e1f4f0e399454397873

commit_message:
Update cookiecutter

- remove real from db.pp
- remove unused variables in params.pp,
because we are usinig oslo to manage db.
- change log_facility to syslog_log_facility,
update tests.

Change-Id: If2154a8d2ae114aec568ccd3d82760c94d2c495f

commit_message:
Add support for the oslo db_max_retries parameter

The db_max_retries parameter regulates the number of reconnection
attempts performed after an error raised rather than at startup.

Change-Id: I28f533d87fbc61f8f16f62e3d2f6087ec6c1c04f
Closes-Bug: 1579718

commit_message:
Make cache_result safer to use

cache_result would cache the same output for multiple calls with different
args and kwars - now it accepts only cls_instance
Also a valid output of "None" was not being cached

Change-Id: Ic2e045980785cc8c0998fe26b03b38c6d2897438

deleted_lines: cache = [None] def wrapper(*args, **kwargs): if cache[0] is not None: return cache[0] else: result = function(*args, **kwargs) cache[0] = result return result

subject: Make registering error handlers compliant with Flask 0.11
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-01 17:43:50.000000000', 'files': ['designate/api/v1/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/58f3a600862b51b19c3b789790157b07fff67e49', 'message': 'Make registering error handlers compliant with Flask 0.11

With Flask 0.11 setting error handlers by directly modifying
app.error_handler_spec dictionary leads to AttributeErrors.
It should be done by using register_error_handler method or
errorhandler decorator.

Change-Id: I4c6cb80a6311c081a30130ba51b8e5d7a88331b2
Closes-Bug: #1587849
'}]
commit_message:
Make registering error handlers compliant with Flask 0.11

With Flask 0.11 setting error handlers by directly modifying
app.error_handler_spec dictionary leads to AttributeErrors.
It should be done by using register_error_handler method or
errorhandler decorator.

Change-Id: I4c6cb80a6311c081a30130ba51b8e5d7a88331b2
Closes-Bug: #1587849

commit_message:
introduce install_dib varible

- This change introduces a new install_dib varible.
- This change decouples installation of disk image
  builder and dib-utils form building a dib image.
- To maintain backwards compatiblity install_dib
  default to the value of create_image_via_dib

Change-Id: I06fb4a2df73702f06393c552f6ba9f705a4eb994
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/22/318422/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- other: - A new install_dib varible has been introduced to the ironic install role to control installation of disk image builder and dib-utils. To maintain the previous behavior install_dib will default to the value of create_image_via_dib.

commit_message:
libvirt: Skip CPU compatibility check for emulated guests

Comparing host to guest CPU model for emulated guests (<domain
type='qemu'>) should not matter -- in this mode the CPU is fully
emulated in software and no hardware acceleration, like KVM, is
involved.

So, skip the CPU compatibility check for the QEMU domain type,
and retain it for KVM guests.

Co-Authored-By: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I8b782678a6dfa7bcfc203381037e1df4475c3194

commit_message:
Remove dot files as well

Remove all of the files except the README - including dot files - for
retiring of the repo.

For details, see:
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#remove-project-content

Also, update README.rst for this so that the checkout instructions are
correct.

Change-Id: I7411e4ebcaa9f55869a4976d8ca6801ed6a3290a

subject: Provide fallback from ATA erase to shredding
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-01 08:23:03.000000000', 'files': ['ironic_python_agent/hardware.py', 'releasenotes/notes/enable-cleaning-fallback-57e8c9aa2f24e63d.yaml', 'ironic_python_agent/tests/unit/test_hardware.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent/commit/b6bdaf040f6cde7f069ea355b7b4b12aea60fbd7', 'message': 'Provide fallback from ATA erase to shredding

Presently should the ATA erasure operation fails, IPA halts the
cleaning process and the node goes to CLEANFAIL state as a result.

This failure could be the result of a previous cleaning failure
that left drive security enabled, for which code has been added
in an attempt to address this case by attempting to unlock the
the drive.

In the event that an operator wishes to automatically fallback to
disk scrubbing operations, the capability has been added through
a driver_internal_info field "agent_continue_if_ata_erase_failed"
that can be set to True, however defaults to False keeping the
